author: O. Conrad, V. Olaya (c) 2002-4
library_description: Tools for (grid based) digital terrain analysis.

tools.author: (c) 2001 by O.Conrad

inputs.description: A grid that contains elevation data.
inputs.name: Elevation

inputs.description:
An optional grid that provides information about flow directions. 
Values between 1 to 8 force the flow of a cell to be given to one its adjacent neighbor cells (1->NE, 2->E, 3->SE, 4->S, 5->SW, 6->W, 7->NW, 8->N). In case of other values the algorithm will use its own routing scheme. 
This option is in particular useful to supply the algorithm with routes that lead the flow through closed depression.
inputs.name: Flow Direction

inputs.description: Dependent on the chosen 'Initiation Type' and 'Initiation Threshold' the values of this grid control where a channel is initiated.
inputs.name: Initiation Grid

outputs.description: If a cell is part of a channel its value equals the channel order. Otherwise the cell is marked as no-data.
outputs.name: Channel Network

outputs.description: If a cell is part of a channel then its value shows the flow direction of the channel (1->NE, 2->E, 3->SE, 4->S, 5->SW, 6->W, 7->NW, 8->N). Otherwise the cell is marked as no-data.
outputs.name: Channel Direction

outputs.description: This shapes layer will contain the resulting channel network in vector format (lines).
outputs.name: Channel Network

optionals.constraints:
Available Choices:
[0] Less than
[1] Equals
[2] Greater than
Default: 2
optionals.description:
Options:
 - Less than
 - Equals
 - Greater than
Controls under which condition a channel is initiated.
optionals.name: Initiation Type

optionals.description: Dependent on the chosen 'Initiation Grid' and 'Initiation Type' this value controls under which condition a channel is initiated.
optionals.name: Initiation Threshold

optionals.description: Tracing: Stop after x cells with divergent flow
optionals.name: Tracing: Max. Divergence

tools.tool_description:
This tool derives a channel network based on gridded digital elevation data.
Use the initiation options to determine under which conditions channels shall start.

tools.author: O.Conrad (c) 2002

inputs.description: A grid that contains elevation data.
inputs.name: Elevation

inputs.description: A grid providing information about the channel network. It is assumed that no-data cells are not part of the channel network. Vice versa all others cells are recognised as channel network members.
inputs.name: Channel Network

outputs.description: The resulting grid gives the altitude above the channel network in the same units as the elevation data.
outputs.name: Vertical Distance to Channel Network

outputs.description: This optional grid output contains the interpolated channel network base level elevations.
outputs.name: Channel Network Base Level

tools.tool_description:
This tool calculates the vertical distance to a channel network base level. The algorithm consists of two major steps:
 1. Interpolation of a channel network base level elevation
 2. Subtraction of this base level from the original elevations

tools.author: O.Conrad (c) 2001-14

inputs.description: A grid that contains elevation data.
inputs.name: Elevation

inputs.description: A grid providing information about the channel network. It is assumed that no-data cells are not part of the channel network. Vice versa all others cells are recognised as channel network members.
inputs.name: Channel Network

inputs.description: Downhill flow is bound to preferred routing cells, where these are not no-data. Helps to model e.g. small ditches, that are not well represented in the elevation data.
inputs.name: Preferred Routing

inputs.description: If set, output is given about the number of fields a flow path visits downhill. For D8 only.
inputs.name: Fields

inputs.description: Manning-Strickler coefficient for flow travel time estimation (reciprocal of Manning's Roughness Coefficient)
inputs.name: Manning-Strickler Coefficient

inputs.description: flow depth [m] for flow travel time estimation
inputs.name: Flow Depth

outputs.description: The overland flow distance in map units. It is assumed that the (vertical) elevation data use the same units as the (horizontal) grid coordinates.
outputs.name: Overland Flow Distance

outputs.description: This is the vertical component of the overland flow
outputs.name: Vertical Overland Flow Distance

outputs.description: This is the horizontal component of the overland flow
outputs.name: Horizontal Overland Flow Distance

outputs.description: flow travel time to channel expressed in hours based on Manning's Equation
outputs.name: Flow Travel Time

outputs.description: This is the horizontal component of the overland flow
outputs.name: Sediment Yield Delivery Ratio

outputs.description: Number of fields a flow path visits downhill starting at a cell. For D8 only.
outputs.name: Fields Visited

optionals.description:
Choose a flow routing algorithm that shall be used for the overland flow distance calculation:
- D8
- MFD
optionals.name: Flow Algorithm

optionals.description: Take cells at the boundary of the DEM as channel.
optionals.name: Boundary Cells

optionals.description: catchment specific parameter for sediment delivery ratio calculation
optionals.name: Beta

optionals.description: default value if no grid has been selected
optionals.name: Default

optionals.description: default value if no grid has been selected
optionals.name: Default

tools.tool_description: This tool calculates overland flow distances to a channel network based on gridded digital elevation data and channel network information. The flow algorithm may be either Deterministic 8 (O'Callaghan & Mark 1984) or Multiple Flow Direction (Freeman 1991). Sediment Delivery Rates (SDR) according to Ali & De Boer (2010) can be computed optionally.
tools.tool_name: Overland Flow Distance to Channel Network

optionals.description: Strahler order to begin a channel.
optionals.name: Threshold

tools.author: Victor Olaya, Volker Wichmann (c) 2004-17

outputs.description: The output data set with encoded Strahler stream order.
outputs.name: Strahler Order

tools.tool_description: This tool allows one to calculate the Strahler stream order on basis of a DEM and the steepest descent (D8) algorithm.

tools.author: O.Conrad (c) 2012
tools.tool_description:
Valley depth is calculated as difference between the elevation and an interpolated ridge level. Ridge level interpolation uses the algorithm implemented in the 'Vertical Distance to Channel Network' tool. It performs the following steps:
 - Definition of ridge cells (using Strahler order on the inverted DEM).
 - Interpolation of the ridge level.
 - Subtraction of the original elevations from the ridge level.
